1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response
PPG Industries, Inc. in Longview, Washington produces chlorine that is considered hazardous by EPA. The Toxicity of chlorine at high concentrations make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human exposure, and to reduce the threat to the personal health of our employees as well as nearby members of the communtiy. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and State rules and regulations. Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle chlorine, the safety devices inherent in the design of the facility, combined with the safe handling procedures that we use and the training of our personnel. 

PPG's emergency response program is designed to effectively respond to an accidental release of chlorine. The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the Local Emergency Planning Commision (LEPC), the Washington Department of Ecology, and the National Response Center. 

2. The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 
The regulated substance handled at the Longview facility is chlorine. The facility produces chlorine by passing an electrical current through a salt-water brine, liberating chlorine and hydrogen from the water. The chlorine is then cooled, dried, and compressed.  Some of the compressed chlorine is used to produce hydrochloric acid in the HCl Synthesis Unit and the remainder is liquefied. The liquefied chlorine is loaded into rail cars and shipped by rail. There is no fixed chlorine storage on site. 

Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors. 

3. Accidental Release Prevention Program
PPG complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations. This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable chlorine storage and handling codes. All employees involved with the operation or ma

intenance of the chlorine system are thoroughly trained using PPG's documented training program. 

4. Five-Year Accident History
No accidental releases of chlorine causing on-site or off-site injury or damage have occurred during the life of the facility. 

5. Emergency Response Program
PPG's emergency response program is based upon an accidental release of chlorine. This program has been discussed with the Cowlitz County Emergency Management and the local Fire Department.
